SENT.plain: BACKGROUND: Preimplantation genetic diagnosis has been used to decrease or avoid the risk of transmitting identified mutations to offspring
CASE: A 29-year-old woman with spondyloepiphyseal dysplasia congenita and her 30-year-old husband with Marfan syndrome underwent in vitro fertilization with preimplantation genetic diagnosis
Two mutation-negative embryos were transferred into a gestational carrier, who became pregnant with twins and delivered two clinically normal neonates
CONCLUSION: Statistically, this couple would be predicted to have a 75% chance of producing an affected embryo
Using preimplantation genetic diagnosis, two dually unaffected embryos were selected and transferred
This experience expands the use of preimplantation genetic diagnosis to cases with multiple autosomal dominant single-gene disorders
